questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with high-grade fever, chills, and severe pain in the right hip. On examination, there is redness, warmth, and swelling in the right hip region. The hip is in FABER attitude with grossly reduced movements. Blood investigations show elevated ESR and WBC count. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Septic Arthritis

Clinical Diagnosis:

  • Septic arthritis is primarily diagnosed through clinical evaluation.
  • Commonly affected joints:
    • Most frequently involves the knee.
    • Other affected joints include the hip, shoulder, and elbow.

Presenting Complaints:

  • Acute Form:
    • The child presents with severe, throbbing pain in the affected joint, along with swelling and redness.
    • High-grade fever and malaise are common.
    • The child is unable to use the affected limb.
  • Subacute Form:
    • The child may exhibit signs of guarding, avoiding movement or contact with the joint.
    • In the lower limbs, a painful limp might be the first symptom noticed.
    • Low-grade fever may be present.

Physical Examination:

  • The child typically appears severely ill with:
    • High fever
    • Tachycardia (elevated heart rate)
  • Joint Examination:
    • The affected joint is swollen and held in a position of comfort (position of ease).
    • Palpation reveals:
      • Increased warmth (temperature)
      • Tenderness
      • Joint effusion (fluid accumulation)
    • Severe limitation of joint movement in all directions.
    • Both passive and active movements induce severe pain and muscle spasms.
  • Subacute cases:
    • Some joint movement may still be possible, though it remains painful.

Option A and B - FABER is the position, increased ESR and WBC both are seen in septic hip/transient synovitis. < 6 yrs age and gross symptoms points more towards septic arthritis than transient synovitis.

Option C- TB hip will not have high grade fever severe pain. Less likely to occur in children.

Option D - No recent history of trauma is mentioned nor any past history about congenital hip dysplasia hence dislocation is ruled out.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number.181.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant is brought to the clinic due to concerns about asymmetric leg movements. The parents report that the baby's left hip appears "looser" than the right, and they've noticed reduced movement in that leg. An X-ray and ultrasound of the hips are ordered, which reveal abnormalities in the acetabular development. Which of the following is NOT a radiological parameter used to diagnose DDH?
questions.solution:
Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH):

  • Involves:
    • Subluxation: Partial dislocation of the femoral head.
    • Complete dislocation: The femoral head is completely dislocated from the true acetabulum.
    • Acetabular dysplasia: Poorly formed acetabulum.
  • Acetabular Index: Option C
    • Angle formed by Hilgenreiner's line and a line from the lateral triradiate cartilage to the lateral margin of the acetabulum.
    • Normal value: less than 25° in children older than 6 months.
    • Seen on X-ray.
  • Alpha Angle: Option B
    • Created by lines along the bony acetabulum and the ilium.
    • Normal value: greater than 60°.
    • Seen on ultrasound (USG).
  • Beta Angle: Option A
    • Formed by lines along the labrum and the ilium.
    • Normal value: less than 55°.
    • Seen on ultrasound (USG).
  • Kite's Angle: Option D
    • Also known as the talo-calcaneal angle.
    • Normal value: between 20-40 degrees.
    • In congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), it is less than 20 degrees.
    • Not used in diagnosing DDH.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 1186

Reference: Tachdjian's Pediatric Orthopaedics 5th edition page number. 499

questions.text: In a child with Perthes disease, which of the following movements of the hip joint is most commonly restricted?
questions.solution:
Perthes Disease Overview

  • Demographics:
    • Common Age Group: Primarily affects boys aged 5-10 years.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms:
      • Pain in the hip, often radiating to the knee.
      • Possible limping.
      • Hip stiffness.
  • Examination Findings: (Option A,B,C and D)
    • Findings may be minimal.
    • Common signs include:
      • Limitation of abduction.
      • Limitation of internal rotation.
      • Shortening of the affected limb.
  • Radiological Findings:
    • X-ray Characteristics:
      • Collapse and sclerosis of the epiphysis of the femoral head.
      • Increased hip joint space.
    • Notably, there can be a striking contrast between the minimal clinical symptoms and signs and the significant X-ray changes observed.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 318.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is brought to the clinic with a 2-month history of worsening back pain, kyphosis and difficulty in walking. He has a history of recent pulmonary tuberculosis. An MRI of the spine is performed to assess for potential vertebral lesions. Based on the typical locations of vertebral lesions in spinal tuberculosis, which of the following locations is not commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Types of Vertebral Tuberculosis

Lesions in the vertebrae may be categorized into the following types:

  1. Paradiscal:
    • Description: This is the most common type of vertebral tuberculosis.
    • Involvement: Affects the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc.
  2. Central:
    • Description: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected.
    • Consequences:
      • Leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra.
      • The nearby disc may remain normal.
      • Collapse can be of two types:
        • Wedging: More common form of collapse.
        • Concertina: Less common.
  3. Anterior:
    • Description: Infection is localized to the anterior part of the vertebral body.
    • Spread: The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  4. Posterior:
    • Description: In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra is affected.
    • Involvement: Affects structures such as the pedicle, lamina, spinous process, and transverse process.

Reference:J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number.186.

questions.text: A 24 year old college student sustained knee injury while playing football. He was advised MRI which shows PCL and postero-lateral corner injury. Which test can be used to examine him clinically ?
questions.solution:
Dial Test for Posterolateral Knee Injury

  • Purpose:
    • To diagnose posterolateral knee injuries.
    • To differentiate between:
      • Isolated Posterolateral Corner (PLC) injury.
      • Combination of PLC and Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) injury.

Tibial External Rotation (Dial) Test:

  • Procedure:
    • The test measures external rotation of the tibia on the femur at two angles of knee flexion: 30 degrees and 90 degrees.
    • The test can be performed with the patient in either a supine or prone position.
  • Interpretation of Results:
    • Isolated PLC Injury:
      • More than a 10-degree increase in external rotation compared to the contralateral side at 30 degrees of knee flexion (but not at 90 degrees) indicates an isolated PLC injury.
    • Combination Injury:
      • Pathologic external rotation exists at 30 degrees of knee flexion, and the external rotation increases when the knee is flexed to 90 degrees. This indicates an injury to both the PCL and PLC.
  • Note:
    • Option C - For an isolated PCL tear, the posterior drawer test or sag test are more appropriate diagnostic tests.
    • Option A and D - Both these tests are for ACL injury.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 2238.

choices.text: Tear of the UCL of MCP joint

questions.text: What is the primary cause of Gamekeeper's thumb?
questions.solution:
Skier's Thumb / Gamekeeper's Thumb

Definition: Option B
Skier's thumb (also known as Gamekeeper's thumb) is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the metacarpo-phalangeal joint of the thumb.

Causes of Injury:

  • Activities:
    • Skiing
    • Holding a catch
    • Twisting the neck of small animals

Types of Injuries:

  1. Acute Injuries (Skier's Thumb)
  2. Chronic Injuries (Gamekeeper's Thumb)

Mechanism of Injury:

  • Forceful thumb hyperextension and/or hyperabduction.
  • Occurs through supination of the proximal phalanx around an intact radial collateral ligament (RCL).

Clinical Considerations:

  • UCL Function: Critical for strong and effective pinch.
  • Tears: Difficult to differentiate between complete and partial tears based on physical examination alone.

Diagnosis:

  • Imaging:
    • Stress radiographs
    • MRI

Treatment Options:

  • Incomplete Rupture:
    • Conservative treatment with a thumb spica cast or functional cast brace.
  • Complete Rupture:
    • Surgical repair is necessary.
  • Stener Lesion:
    • Occurs in approximately 85% of complete injuries when the adductor pollicis aponeurosis becomes interposed between the retracted ligament, hindering healing.
    • Requires surgical reattachment of the ligament through drill holes, suture anchor, or interference screw.
  • Large Displaced Avulsion Fracture:
    • Requires Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF).

Reference. Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number:1446.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with giving way of the left knee after a slip and fall while walking. Clinical examination reveals a positive valgus stress test at 30 degrees of flexion. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Mechanisms of Knee Ligament Injuries

Knee ligaments are most often injured from indirect, twisting, or bending forces. Below are the specific mechanisms of injury for each ligament:

  1. Medial Collateral Ligament (MCL) Option C
    • Mechanism of Injury:
      • Damaged by a valgus force, which abducts the leg on the femur.
    • Common Injury Pattern:
      • Ruptures most commonly at its femoral attachment.
  2. Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) Option D
    • Mechanism of Injury:
      • Injured by a varus force, which adducts the tibia on the femur.
    • Common Injury Pattern:
      • Often avulsed from the head of the fibula along with a piece of bone.
    • Note:
      • LCL injuries are uncommon as the knee is rarely subjected to varus forces (e.g., being hit from the inside).
  3. Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Option A
    • Mechanism of Injury:
      • Most commonly ruptured due to twisting forces on a semi-flexed knee.
    • Common Injury Pattern:
      • Often occurs in association with tears of the MCL and lateral collateral ligaments.
      • This combination is known as O'Donoghue triad.
  4. Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) Option B
    • Mechanism of Injury:
      • Damaged when the anterior aspect of the tibia is struck while the knee is semi-flexed, forcing the tibia backwards onto the femur.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:149.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a noticeable asymmetry of her shoulders. Upon examination, the left shoulder appears higher than the right, and there is limited range of motion in her left arm. The patient's mother reports that she has not noticed any pain or discomfort. The child is otherwise healthy and active in sports. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sprengel Deformity

Definition:
Sprengel deformity is characterized by a congenital upward elevation of the scapula in relation to the thoracic cage. The affected scapula is often hypoplastic (underdeveloped) and misshapen.

Associated Anomalies:

  • Common Congenital Anomalies:
    • Cervical ribs / Malformations of ribs
    • Klippel-Feil syndrome (occurs in one-third of cases)
    • Kidney disease
    • Scoliosis
    • Diastematomyelia
  • Omovertebral Bone:
    • Present in about half of patients.
    • A rhomboidal plaque of cartilage and bone that extends from the superior angle of the scapula to the spinous process, lamina, or transverse process of one or more lower cervical vertebrae.
    • This structure prevents the descent of the scapula.

Clinical Features:

  • Characteristics:
    • Undescended scapula often associated with winging, hypoplasia, and omovertebral connections (present in 30% of cases).
    • Most common congenital anomaly of the shoulder in children.
    • Affected scapulae are usually small, relatively wide, and medially rotated.

Treatment Options:

  • Surgery may be indicated for cosmetic or functional deformities (e.g., decreased abduction).
  • Surgical Procedures:
    • Woodward Procedure: Distal advancement of associated muscles and scapula.
    • Schrock and Green Procedures: Detachment and movement of the scapula.
  • Expected Outcomes: Both surgical options can improve abduction by 40-50 degrees.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 1231

Reference. Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number. 548.

choices.text: Posteromedial soft tissue release is the initial treatment of choice
Ideal treatment is manipulation and casting
Kite's method takes longer period to correct the deformity

questions.text: All are true regarding CTEV except :
questions.solution:
Manipulation and casting for Clubfoot Treatment

Overview

In the treatment of clubfoot, the surgeon manipulates the foot after sedating the child. The foot is then held in the corrected position using plaster casts. There are two main philosophies for the treatment of clubfoot: Kite's method and Ponsetti's method.

  1. Kite's Method
    • Correction Rate: Achieves correction in approximately 30% of cases.
    • Duration: Treatment takes place over a period of 6-9 months. (Option D)
    • Current Use: This method is not commonly used today.
  2. Ponsetti's Philosophy
    • Basis: This approach is grounded in a better understanding of the pathoanatomy of the deformed foot. (Option C)
    • It is to be started in first week of life itself. (Option A)
    • Correction Timeline: It is usually possible to correct all components of the deformity within 6 weeks.
    • Current Use: This method is widely used around the world.

Operative Methods

In cases of more severe deformities that do not respond to conservative methods, or in cases of recurrence, operative treatment may be necessary (Option B). The following approaches are commonly used:

  1. Soft Tissue Release Operations
    • Indicated for younger children (under 3 years old).
    • Postero-Medial Soft Tissue Release (PMSTR):
      • Description: This operation involves the release of tight soft tissue structures (including tendons, ligaments, and the joint capsule) on the posterior and medial side of the foot.
      • Age Consideration: PMSTR can be performed in younger children; however, older children may require an additional bony procedure.
  2. Bony Operations
    • Required for older children with more severe deformities.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 214.

choices.text: It is associated with Vickers ligament.

questions.text: Regarding Madelung deformity, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Madelung Deformity

Overview

Madelung deformity is characterized by defective growth of the distal radial epiphysis, leading to deformity of the distal end of the radius and dorsal dislocation of the head of the ulna.

Key Features

  • Disruption: Involves disruption of the volar ulnar physis of the distal radius (Option C).
  • Tethering Structure: The implicated tethering structure is the Vickers ligament (Option B), a fibrous band running from the distal radius to the lunate on the volar aspect of the wrist (radio-lunate ligament).

Developmental Changes

  • As the child grows, the distal radius exhibits:
    • Excessive radial inclination.
    • Volar tilt.
  • These changes represent a spectrum of abnormality observed in the condition.

Clinical Presentation

  • Often asymptomatic and may be discovered incidentally in adulthood, typically following a minor wrist injury that prompts radiographic examination.

Symptoms

  • Symptoms can arise from:
    • Ulnocarpal impaction.
    • Restricted forearm rotation.
    • Median nerve compression.

Treatment Options

  • Early Release: Surgical release of the Vickers ligament.
  • Corrective Osteotomy: May involve corrective osteotomy of the radius, with or without distal ulna resection.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 225

Reference: Miller's review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number. 1603.

questions.text: A 13 year old girl presents with multiple swellings and brown rashes. Bone scan shows increased uptake over femur and ribs. Bio-chemical parameters are abnormal. She also has hypothyroidism and her xray looks as below. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
McCune-Albright Syndrome

McCune-Albright Syndrome is characterized by three primary features:

  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Café-au-lait spots
  • Precocious puberty

Fibrous Dysplasia

  • Definition: A developmental abnormality of bone characterized by monostotic (single bone) or polyostotic (multiple bones) involvement. It represents a failure in the normal production of lamellar bone.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Patients may experience pain due to a fracture or stress fracture, or it may be asymptomatic and found incidentally.
    • Café-au-lait spots with irregular borders, resembling the "coast of Maine," often accompany the bone lesions.
    • Any bone can be affected, though the proximal femur is the most commonly involved site.
  • Imaging:
    • Variable radiographic appearance, ranging from highly lytic lesions to a "ground glass" appearance on X-ray.
    • Bone scans often reveal multiple areas of uptake.
  • Histology:
    • Fibrous dysplasia presents with trabeculae of osteoid and bone within fibrous stroma arranged in a disorganized manner. This pattern is often described as resembling "alphabet soup" or "Chinese letters."
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is based on symptom severity and fracture risk.
    • Internal fixation and bone grafting are typically used in high-stress areas where nonoperative treatments are insufficient.
    • Most patients do not require surgical intervention.

Additional Features

  • When fibrous dysplasia is accompanied by endocrine abnormalities (especially precocious puberty) and café-au-lait spots, the condition is classified as McCune-Albright Syndrome.

Reference:Miller’s review of Orthopaedics 8th edition page number:1903

questions.text: A kabaddi player presented with severe pain, swelling and bony swelling after injury to left shoulder joint while practising. His xray is as follows. Identify the injured structures.
questions.solution:
AC Joint Overview

The Acromioclavicular (AC) Joint is a diarthrodial joint characterized by the following features:

  • Articular Surfaces: The joint consists of fibrocartilage-covered surfaces located between the lateral end of the clavicle and the medial acromion.
  • Joint Plane:
    • The inclination of the joint plane can be either vertical or inclined medially at approximately 50 degrees.
  • Ligamentous Support:
    • The joint is reinforced by the AC ligaments (Option A), which include:
      • Anterior AC ligament
      • Posterior AC ligament
      • Superior AC ligament
      • Inferior AC ligament
    • The thin joint capsule is strengthened by the fibers of the deltoid and trapezius muscles that blend with the superior AC ligament.
  • Mobility:
    • The AC joint exhibits minimal mobility due to the presence of a meniscoid intra-articular disc. This disc undergoes age-dependent degeneration, becoming essentially nonfunctional after the fourth decade of life.
  • Stability:
    • Horizontal Stability: Provided by the AC ligaments.
    • Vertical Stability: Maintained by the coracoclavicular ligaments (Option B), which consist of:
      • Conoid ligament (medial)
      • Trapezoid ligament (lateral)
    • The deltoid and trapezius fascial attachments further reinforce the superior AC ligament, acting as secondary stabilizers for vertical stability.
  • Coracoclavicular Distance:
    • The average distance between the coracoid and clavicle is approximately 1.1 to 1.3 cm.

Reference: Handbook of fractures by Koval, 5th edition page number:143

questions.text: Best method of investigation in septic arthritis is?
questions.solution:
Investigations for Septic Arthritis

Radiological Examination

  • Importance: Early diagnosis is crucial, but X-rays are usually normal in the initial stages.
  • Findings:
    • Careful evaluation of X-rays may reveal:
      • Increased joint space
      • Soft tissue shadow corresponding to the distended capsule due to swelling.
    • In later stages:
      • Joint space may become narrowed.
      • Irregularities of the joint margins may be observed.
      • Possible subluxation or dislocation of the joint.

Ultrasound Examination (Option B and C)

  • Useful for detecting fluid collections in deep joints such as the hip and shoulder.
  • If fluid is detected, aspiration can be performed to obtain a sample for culture to identify the causative organism.

Blood Tests

  • Blood Findings:
    • Neutrophilic leucocytosis is typically observed.
    • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Markedly elevated.
    • Blood cultures may grow the causative organism. (Option D)

Joint Aspiration

  • Considered the quickest and most effective method for diagnosing septic arthritis.

Fluid Analysis:

  • The aspirated fluid may demonstrate features of acute septic inflammation. In case of a deep joint infection, ultrasound examination can help detect increased intra-articular fluid. Ultrasound guided aspiration can be done.
    • Gram Staining: Provides initial clues regarding the type of organism, pending culture results.
  • In case of septic arthritis, early surgical drainage saves the joint from permanent damage. Instead of open drainage, arthroscopic drainage is better.
  • Staph. aureus is the most common organism responsible.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 181

questions.text: Match the injuries with commonly used treatment modalities:
questions.solution:
1. Repair of Ligaments
    • Indication: Performed for fresh, grade III collateral ligament injuries.
    • Procedure:
      • For injuries presenting 2-3 weeks after the initial trauma, additional reinforcement is provided using a fascial or tendon graft.
  2. Reconstruction of Ligaments
    • Common Injury: The Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) is the most frequently ruptured ligament.
    • Treatment of Choice:
      • Arthroscopic ACL Reconstruction:
        • The torn ligament is replaced with a tendon graft.
        • This procedure is performed endoscopically (arthroscopically), allowing for surgery without the need to open the joint.
  3. Salter-Harris (SCH) Fractures in Children
    • Treatment Approach:
      • Most displaced fractures can be reduced through closed reduction.
      • Due to the risk of slippage, it is advisable to fix these fractures with one or two K-wires, which are passed percutaneously (Closed Reduction Internal Fixation - CRIF) under image intensifier guidance.
  4. Femoral Mid-Shaft Fracture
    • Preferred Treatment Method:
      • For most femoral shaft fractures, closed nailing is the standard approach.
      • Procedure:
        • The fracture is reduced under X-ray control (using an image intensifier) without opening the fracture site.
        • A nail (a type of rod) is introduced into the medullary canal from the greater trochanter while being monitored by the image intensifier.

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 98, 150, 142.

questions.text: A 34 year old male came to the OPD with complaints of right hip pain and limping for the last 4 months. On examination, the limb was found to have true shortening of 2 cms. MRI shows signs of TB hip. Which stage of tuberculosis hip is the patient in?
questions.solution:
Stage 3 of TB hip (Stage of arthritis)

In this stage, significant changes occur in the hip joint:

  • Cartilage Destruction:
    • The cartilage is destroyed, leading to erosion of the femoral head and/or the acetabulum.
  • Joint Displacement:
    • No significant joint displacement/ dislocation.
  • Limb Position:
  • The attitude of the limb remains similar to that in Stage II, characterized by:
    • Flexion
    • Adduction
    • Internal Rotation
  • However, the deformities are more pronounced in this advanced stage.
  • Limb Shortening:
    • True Shortening: There is an actual shortening of the limb due to the destruction of bone.
    • Apparent Length Reduction: The apparent length of the limb is further decreased because of the adduction deformity.

Reference: SM Tuli’s book of Tuberculosis, 2nd Edition page number: 72
